body:
Hi @abaveja313, can you provide more information about the type of model you deployed to SageMaker and, if applicable, the conda environment associated with the model?

The gunicorn log statements are normal and should not be the cause of the health check failure. Is there any additional log output from CloudWatch that you can find?

Thanks for your quick response! I am trying to deploy a pyspark RandomForestClasssifier model. Here is the model I am trying to deploy This is my conda.yaml file: ``` conda_yaml_contents = \ """ name: pyspark_conda channels: - defaults dependencies: - python=3.6 - numpy=1.14.3 - pandas=0.22.0 - scikit-learn=0.19.1 - h2o - pip: - pyspark==2.2.2 - mlflow==0.8.0 """ ``` Thanks so much!

It seems as if some other events took place:
```
pip 10.0.1 from /miniconda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pip (python 3.7)
```

@abaveja313 Thank you for providing additional log output. I'm still not seeing a clear indication of failure from the CloudWatch information you've provided.

I'll try deploying a model with the conda environment you specified. What flavor of MLflow model did you save (`sklearn`, `spark`, `h2o`, etc)?
> @abaveja313  How did you solve it? Did you do what @dbczumar suggested ?
@Vishnunkumar I did and it worked. I still cannot deploy a ml.t2.medium instance, but large and xl work.

hi, could you re-open this incident? 

I have tried will larger instances, but unable to get through.
also try adding gunicorn and nginx to requirements.txt as mentioned in other blogs.

Error Message:
2022/02/20 13:18:25 [crit] 22#22: *213 connect() to unix:/tmp/gunicorn.sock failed (2: No such file or directory) while connecting to upstream, client: 10.32.0.2, server: , request: "GET /ping HTTP/1.1", upstream: "http://unix:/tmp/gunicorn.sock:/ping", host: "model.aws.local:8080"
